properties.name: Barn Corn Crib
properties.notes:
Barn Corn Crib https://www.nps.gov/places/barn-corn-crib.htm Access to see this building is limited due to Covid-19.

Constructed in 1923 this corn crib originally stored corn grown on the farm and fed to the livestock raised by second owner Ellison Smyth.  The Sandburg's stored various farm equipment here and today garden tools are stored inside.

properties.name: Barn Garage
properties.notes:
Barn Garage https://www.nps.gov/places/barn-garage.htm

The interior of this building is currently closed due to Covid-19

The Sandburg's stored farm equipment including the farm tractor and jeep in this building.  Occasionally the equipment was removed for evening square dances, including a group known as the Connemara Farm Dancers.

Listen to the audio to hear Sandburg's granddaughter Paula Steichen talk about the square dances held here.

"The garage at the barn was often used for square dances on Saturday nights. When we had a caretaker Frank Mintz for quite a time who was part of a dancing group, a mountain dancing group, and we would have square dances, he would really hold the square dances there, and sometimes members of the family would go down. I know that Frank Mintz’s group for a while wore the shirts that said Chickaming Goat Herd on them."

properties.name: Be a Junior Ranger at the Sandburg Home
properties.notes:
Be a Junior Ranger at the Sandburg Home https://www.nps.gov/places/carl-jr-ranger.htm

Visit Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site and become a Junior Ranger!

Visit the weekend pop-up park store and information area behind the Sandburg Home and ask for a free Junior Ranger program or download a digital booklet before you visit. Then, explore the park to complete the activities appropriate for your age, show it to a ranger, and you will earn a badge and the honor of being a Junior Ranger who vows to learn about and protect National Parks throughout our country.

If you cannot visit Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site, simply download a Junior Ranger booklet. For a Spanish language booklet, plelase email the park. You can use the museum web exhibit to find the information needed to complete the activities, then mail or scan and email the booklet to the park for a ranger to check. We will mail the booklet back to you with your badge. In order to be efficient with mail, we only mail badges/completed booklets back to visitors. If you have questions about the program, please contact the park by email.

properties.name: Bean Lake, Missouri
properties.notes:
Bean Lake, Missouri https://www.nps.gov/places/bean-lake-missouri.htm

The next stop was the railroad section gang at Bean Lake, Missouri. After doing intense, hard labor for two weeks, because of financial struggles for the railroad and the fact that Sandburg didn't have an address at the time, he wasn't paid for his work.

He writes:

My Irish boss, Fay Connors, hired me at a dollar and twenty-five cents a day and I was to pay him three dollars a week for board and room in his four-room one-story house thirty feet from the railroad tracks. I tamped ties several days from seven till noon, from one till six in the evening. On Sunday I washed my shirt and socks. At the end of two weeks, on a Sunday morning, I hopped a freight for Kansas City and left Boss Connors to collect for my board and room out of my paycheck. The rest of the pay was still owing and was never collected. If Connors did get it he couldn’t have sent it to me, as he didn’t know my address and I wasn’t expecting to have any address for weeks or months.

properties.name: Buck Kid Quarters
properties.notes:
Buck Kid Quarters https://www.nps.gov/places/buck-kid-quarters.htm

Access to see this building is limited due to Covid-19.

Mrs. Sandburg housed her young buck kids in this building and adjacent play yard until they were old enough to join the older bucks or be shipped off to other dairy goat farms. 

Today the park uses this building and play yard in the spring for does and their new kids.  Later in the summer, once the buck kids reach four to six months old they are separated from the herd and housed here until they are large enough to join older bucks across the road or are sold to another farm.

properties.name: Chicken House
properties.notes:
Chicken House https://www.nps.gov/places/chicken-house.htm

Constructed in the 1840's the first owner of this property, Christopher Memminger, housed enslaved persons in this building while he lived here in the summers.  Living near the main house they likely helped with domestic tasks of cooking and cleaning, however little is known about these early enslaved workers.

The second owner, Ellison Smyth installed large wash tubs in 1924 and called it the "wash house".

In modern times, Mrs. Sandburg used the left side of the building for chickens and the right side for young goats.

Sandburg's granddaughter, Paula Steichen discusses how the family used the building.

"It was used first for chickens, and then we used it primarily for baby kids that we raised after the kids were old enough to be moved from in the basement of our house, we would take them out there. The kids of course were separated from the does as soon as they were born so they had to be kept in separate quarters."

properties.name: Cow, Chicken and Storage sheds
properties.notes:
Cow, Chicken and Storage sheds https://www.nps.gov/places/cow-chicken-and-storage-sheds.htm

Access to see this building is limited due to Covid-19.

The Sandburg's kept a family milk cow in this shed and sawdust for the goat barn in the storage shed behind it.

Today the cow shed is used to care for chickens of similar breeds to those Mrs. Sandburg raised. The Sandburg chickens were housed in a building up the road by the main house.  Saw dust for the goat barn is still stored in the shed behind it.

properties.name: Crow's Nest
properties.notes:
Crow's Nest
https://www.nps.gov/places/crow-s-nest.htm

This room was named the "Crow's Nest" by Mrs. Sandburg's brother, Edward Steichen.  He likened the room to the lookout on a naval ship because of the beautiful mountain views the family enjoyed from the large window.  Carl Sandburg considered using this room for a study, but decided the view was too distracting.

properties.name: Denver, Colorado
properties.notes:
Denver, Colorado https://www.nps.gov/places/denver-colorado.htm

Sandburg took a Colorado Midland train to head back east to Denver. This was the first time Sandburg "rode the bumpers" (the couplers between train cars) late at night. He was so exhausted that he fell asleep while standing on the bumpers and later considered himself very lucky he didn't fall to his death that night.

In Denver, Sandburg found work in the Windsor, a high-class hotel, washing dishes.

He writes:

I saw Pikes Peak so I could say I saw it... I washed dishes for two weeks, collected a dollar and fifty cents a week, a cubbyhole for a room and meals as good as were served to the silk-hat guests. Then came the question whether I should head for the West coast or east to Galesburg. I admitted I was a little homesick for the faces and streets of Galesburg.

After this stint in Denver, Sandburg headed back to his hometown.

properties.name: Dining Room
properties.notes:
Dining Room https://www.nps.gov/places/dining-room.htm

The aromas of freshly baked breads, hearty soups or homemade pies filled the Sandburg dining room. Most meals included fresh garden salads, yogurt, goat's milk, and Mrs. Sandburg's special cheeses. Carl Sandburg's red thermos contained fresh brewed coffee with goat's milk and a spoonful of honey.  

While they were a very busy and independent family with a host of varied interests, they came together whenever possible for lunch and dinner. After dinner, Sandburg would often play his guitar for a family sing-a-long, or read from his current work.  Or they might turn on the radio to hear Jack Benny, Fibber McGee and Molly or the evening news. Birds entertained outside while they sat around the table.

properties.name: Emporia, Kansas
properties.notes:
Emporia, Kansas https://www.nps.gov/places/emporia-kansas.htm

Traveling further west to find work for the Kansas wheat harvest, Sandburg headed to Emporia. The trip between Kansas City and Emporia was eventful. The young hobo hopped a train and snuck onto a car, but he was discovered by a "shack" (term used for a train brakeman) during the trip. After punching Sandburg twice in the face the shack left him to ride the train.

In his autobiography, Sandburg reminisced about an early interest in newspaper reporting:

I walked past the office of the Emporia Gazette but didn’t have the nerve to step in and ask the editor, William Allen White, how he came to write “What’s the Matter with Kansas?” I didn’t agree with it but I liked his style. After a big two-bit meal I went to the city park, where I lay on the grass for a sleep.

properties.name: Farm Office
properties.notes:
Farm Office https://www.nps.gov/places/farm-office.htm

From her office in the middle of the house, Mrs. Sandburg paid the bills, answered correspondence and kept both the house and farm running smoothly.  She took care of the day to day business so that her husband could focus on his writing.

In order to manage the large goat herd, Mrs. Sandburg was often in her office studying goat lineages, calculating bloodlines and making breeding decisions based on science. She was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate from the University of Chicago, and had a keen interest in genetics. She sold milk to local dairies, sold goats to North and South America, and kept an active schedule of showing goats at regional contests.

Click the audio below to learn how Mrs. Sandburg and her daughter Helga first started raising dairy goats.

"While we were in Michigan, one of the children, our youngest Helga, wanted a cow and then Carl was the one who said, you can’t possibly handle a cow, but a goat would be the right one for your size to handle. Goats you can just put in the family car and drive off, she went with me anyway to see about the goats since her father really said no, that a cow was impossible. We had some goats near the house, and I not only went home with one goat, but I said two goats, we’ll certainly need two goats if we’re going to have our family milk supply. Those goats turned out to be way out of the ordinary goats, that’s how we got into having goats".

properties.name: Flat Rock Outcrop
properties.notes:
Flat Rock Outcrop https://www.nps.gov/places/flat-rock-outcrop.htm This large, exposed rock was a favorite location for Carl Sandburg to bring a chair and orange crate for an outdoors study. He enjoyed the quiet and peacefulness of this location to edit his work. Exposed rocks like this are located throughout the area and have a long history of use going back to the first peoples to settle the area we know today as Flat Rock.

This area’s dynamic and ecologically abundant landscape supplied generations of Native Americans a place to develop extensive cultural traditions related to kinship, religion, trade, art, and diverse use of abundant natural resources. Over millennia, these traditions evolved, adapting to environmental and social changes.Take a moment to pause here and reflect on the legacy of this land! These mountains are clothed in a lush hardwood forest teeming with birds, wildlife and an abundance of native berries, nuts, fruit, and flowers.  

Long ago, native peoples such as Cherokee, Cheraw, and Catawba thrived on this rich abundance.While villages were in outlying areas, these large “flat rocks” near the border of North and South Carolina, were noted as places for traders, pioneers, and settlers to barter goods with the native people. With increased European expansion, the Indian Removal Act of 1838 forced native people to leave their homelands and their ancestral lands were confiscated.

This removal was devastating, and many thousands perished on what is tragically remembered as the Trail of Tears. Today descendants of these early Cherokee people embrace their rich ancestry and culture and call these mountains home again in Cherokee, NC. Learn more about the Trail of Tears.

properties.name: Front Porch
properties.notes:
Front Porch https://www.nps.gov/places/front-porch.htm

Carl Sandburg stood on the porch of his new home in Flat Rock, NC, and declared, "We didn’t just buy two-hundred and forty-five acres when we bought Connemara, we bought a million acres of sky!  They also found at Connemara a writer’s sanctuary and the perfect farm for dairy goats.

As you tour the house you will note that the Sandburg family lived casually.  Simplicity was the rule as indicated by the functional furnishings.

Sandburg followed this philosophy throughout his life, having written to his soon-to-be wife Lilian in 1908, “All the big people are simple, as simple as the unexplored wilderness. They love the universal things that are free to everybody. Light and air and food and love and some work are enough. In the varying phases of these cheap and common things, the great lives have found their joy.”

Connemara provided them all these things; mountain air, gardens and orchards full of vegetables and fruit, plenty of work, and the love of a family.

properties.name: Galesburg Illinois
properties.notes:
Galesburg Illinois https://www.nps.gov/places/galesburg-illinois.htm

Galesburg was Carl Sandburg's hometown - where his hobo journey began and ended.

In Sandburg's autobiography "Always the Young Strangers" he wrote:

The family didn’t like the idea. Papa scowled. Mama kissed me and her eyes had tears after dinner one noon when I walked out of the house with my hands free, no bag or bundle, wearing a black-sateen shirt, coat, vest, and pants, a slouch hat, good shoes and socks, no underwear, in my pockets a small bar of soap, a razor, a comb, a pocket mirror, two handkerchiefs, a piece of string, needles and thread, a Waterbury watch, a knife, a pipe and a sack of tobacco, three dollars and twenty-five cents in cash.

A little west of the Santa Fe station stood a freight train. A conductor came out of the station and waved a yellow flimsy in his hand. As the train started I ran along and jumped into a boxcar. From then on I stood at the open side door, watched the running miles of young corn, reading such station names as Cameron and Stronghurst, names of villages and towns I had heard a thousand times and had never had sight of.

properties.name: Goat Barn
properties.notes:
Goat Barn https://www.nps.gov/places/connemara-virtual-grounds-tour-goat-barn.htm

Access to see the goat barn is limited due to Covid-19.

The goat barn sheltered the does (girl goats) at Connemara.  Mrs. Sandburg operated a successfull dairy, selling milk from the farm to dairies in Asheville and Greenville.  Many of the farm's goats won top awards at state and local fairs. Jennifer II, a Toggenburg dairy goat, was internationally recognized as the top producing Toggenburg in the world in 1960. 

Mrs. Sandburg helped establish the American Dairy Goat Association, located in Spindale, NC, and was its Director for over ten years. She was honored with a lifetime directorship. A legend in the dairy goat industry, Mrs. Paula Sandburg was a champion of champions.

properties.name: Goat Sheds
properties.notes:
Goat Sheds
https://www.nps.gov/places/goat-sheds.htm

Mrs. Sandburg used these sheds when goats were ill and needed to be isolated from the main herd.  The shed on the right was also sometimes referred to as the "breeding shed" as goats would be brought here in the fall for breeding.  Today only one shed is in use and it houses the bucks (boy goats).  The bucks are separated from the does once they reach four to six months old to prevent unplanned breeding.

properties.name: Greenhouse and Garden
properties.notes:
Greenhouse and Garden https://www.nps.gov/places/greenhouse-and-garden.htm

Built in 1873 this building served originally as a root cellar.  The Sandburg's used the greenhouse side to start plants for the flower gardens and occasionally stored bulbs in its cellar.

Adjacent to the greenhouse, the Sandburg's cleared up to an acre for a vegetable garden.  The garden provided much of their own food for the year through canning, drying and preservation.  Still used each year to pant a variety of vegetables, this garden retains a strong association with its past.

properties.name: Hikers' Parking Lot
properties.notes:
Hikers' Parking Lot https://www.nps.gov/places/hikers-parking-lot.htm

Free parking is available at either the main visitor parking lot or hikers' parking lot.  Visitors using the hikers' parking lot will enter from the opposite side of the park as the main parking lot. There is a gravel road to use to walk into the park to access hiking trails, the Sandburg Home, goat farm and grounds. Please use the map in the parking lot to orient yourself when you visit, or view a trail map here. If you need accessibility assistance, please call 828-707-8125 when you arrive and visit our accessibility page for more information.

Oversize Vehicles
The Hikers' lot cannot accomodate large vehicles such as buses, RVs or towable trailers. Please use the Main Visitor parking lot if arriving with a larger vehicle.

Additional Parking Options

  • Visitors may park behind the Flat Rock Village Offices located at 110 Village Center Drive, Flat Rock, NC. It is a short walk to the park from this lot.
  • Visitors may use the Flat Rock Playhouse lot directly across the street from the main visitor lot, in the morning until noon, and in the afternoon when there are no performances. There will be signs posted at the playhouse to restrict parking for performances. Please be a courteous neighbor and pay attention to their signs.
* If you park at Flat Rock Playhouse, remember to move your car before noon or risk being blocked in for several hours on matinee days (Wednesday through Sunday).

Accessibility
Due to the nature of the gravel surfaces and terrain, this parking lot is not accessible, nor does it provide an accessible route into the park. Visitors with accessiblity needs should use the main visitor parking lot. Signs are posted there on how to contact a ranger for assistance.

properties.name: House Garage
properties.notes:
House Garage
https://www.nps.gov/places/house-garage.htm

From 1838 until 1945 this was the kitchen for residents of Connemara.  The Sandburg's modernized the main house with an interior kitchen and converted this building into a three-car garage.  Today the interior is used for special events and programs.

properties.name: Hutchinson, Kansas
properties.notes:
Hutchinson, Kansas https://www.nps.gov/places/hutchinson-kansas.htm

In Hutchinson, Sandburg learned that people who lived near the tracks were less likely to help out errant travelers because they were approached so often.

In his autobiography, he remembered:

I walked eight or ten blocks and hit two houses. "Have you got any work I can do for breakfast?" They took one look at me and shut the door. At the third house a woman sent her daughter to get me a saw, showed me a woodpile and a sawbuck. For an hour I kept the saw going, piled the wood, and went to the house.The smiling mother and daughter led me to the family table, set fried ham and potatoes, apple sauce, bread and coffee, before me.

properties.name: Janet's Bedroom
properties.notes:
Janet's Bedroom
https://www.nps.gov/places/janet-s-bedroom.htm

Sandburg's middle daughter Janet helped out with the farm work, getting up every morning at 5:30 am to feed the baby goats.  Later in the day she helped with the housework.  In her room, she read, drew, wrote letters, and compiled scrapbooks.

properties.name: Kansas City, Missouri
properties.notes:
Kansas City, Missouri https://www.nps.gov/places/kansas-city-missouri.htm

After arriving in Kansas City, Sandburg had little trouble finding his next job.

In Kansas City Mrs. Mullin had a sign in the window of her restaurant on Armour Avenue, “Dishwasher Wanted.” ... It was a fight in that dish trough to get enough dirty dishes cleaned for serving the customers. I swept the eating room morning and afternoon and mopped it on Saturday. My sleeping place was the end of a hallway with my cot curtained off, and I washed and shaved, using my pocket mirror, at a sink and faucet in the hall... I worked every weekday till eight o’clock at night except for an hour or two in the afternoon. I had three good meals a day. I had Sunday off and walked miles around Kansas City comparing it to Galesburg, Peoria, Keokuk, and Chicago.

properties.name: Keokuk, Iowa
properties.notes:
Keokuk, Iowa https://www.nps.gov/places/keokuk-iowa.htm

His arrival in Keokuk marked the first time Sandburg had ventured outside the state of Illinois. He later remembered seeing the Mississippi River for the first time as one of the most awe-inspring sites on his whole journey.

Crossing the long bridge over the Mississippi my eyes swept over it with a sharp hunger that the grand old river satisfied.

A captain of a small steamboat offered the young Sandburg passage to Keokuk for work "shouldering kegs of nails to the wharves."

It was in Keokuk that Sandburg met his first fellow hobo. This man was a "tramp," which meant he didn't work for money, but instead relied on the kindness of strangers to survive. He taught Sandburg that a "lump" meant food that was given as a handout, and "sit down" was a phrase used when someone would invite a tramp to the kitchen table to eat.

Sandburg also found work in Keokuk that would provide some extra cash and meals. He spent a day going door-to-door with a can of asphaltum for blackening rusty stoves, and then:

I saw a sign “Waiter Wanted” in a small lunch counter near the end of Main Street. He said I could make myself useful at 50 cents a day and meals.

After a day working at the lunch counter, Sandburg slept that night in a boxcar that took him halfway across Missouri.

properties.name: Lakin, Kansas
properties.notes:
Lakin, Kansas https://www.nps.gov/places/lakin-kansas.htm

In Lakin, Sandburg took advantage of the Kansas wheat harvest by working for another threshing crew for about three weeks.

The work came easier with getting used to it. The dust in your nose and eyes, the chaff sliding down your sweating back, you got used to. One evening at six o'clock the boss said there was only two hours of threshing left and a full moon would be up. We ate supper, at seven went on threshing by the light of a bright full moon, and finished at nine o'clock.

On Sandburg's trip out of Lakin, a "shack" (train brakeman) kicked him off the bumpers of a fast freight. Riding the bumpers refers to standing on the couplers between two cars and keeping hold of the brake rod for stability. It was extremely dangerous.

properties.name: Larned, Kansas
properties.notes:
Larned, Kansas https://www.nps.gov/places/larned-kansas.htm

Larned was the one place on Carl Sandburg's journey where he refused to refer to himself as a hobo. His father had owned and paid taxes on a quarter section of land in that town.

He wrote in his autobiography:

When I walked past the courthouse I felt like an important, respectable citizen, even though I was sleeping in empty boxcars that stood on the Santa Fe tracks.

Sandburg's work in Larned included assisting a local carpenter for three days at seventy five cents a day and a wheat threshing crew for five days.

properties.name: Lindsborg, Kansas
properties.notes:
Lindsborg, Kansas https://www.nps.gov/places/lindsborg-kansas.htm

After a day in Hutchinson, Sandburg traveled to Lindsborg - a predominantly Swedish community. He worked a hay and broomcorn harvest with several other Swedes on a farm near Lindsborg. Although he was staying among people of the same heritage, Sandburg didn't necessarily get along with them.

I stayed three days at a dollar a day and meals, sleeping in a barn hayloft. On my third and last morning I had been awake a few minutes when I heard voices down below. One voice came clear to me, a Swede saying, "Is that bum up yet?" I said to myself, "Am I a bum?" And I answered, "Yes, I am a bum."... The first time in my life that I heard myself referred to as a bum was among Swedes I had made a detour to see.

properties.name: Main Visitor Parking Lot
properties.notes:
Main Visitor Parking Lot https://www.nps.gov/places/main-parking.htm The pedestrian bridge over the Front Lake dam at the main park entrance is closed. To access park buildings, restrooms, and trails on foot during the closure, visitors must now walk an additional 0.4 mile around Front Lake, and then walk 1/3 mile up a steeply graded hill to the Sandburg Home and farm. Be prepared for this detour when you arrive. View a trail map with the detour here. If you need accessibility assistance, please call 828-707-8125 when you arrive and visit our accessibility page for more information.

Due to the Front Lake bridge closure, a shuttle service is available on Thursdays, Fridays, Saturdays, and Sundays from Friday, September 2 – Sunday, October 30, 2022. The free shuttle will transport visitors from the main parking lot, on Little River Road, to the Sandburg Home and goat farm.

Free parking is available at the entrance to the park. The parking lot has three oversize vehicle parking spaces for RV's and buses. Vehicles with trailers will be unable to park in these spaces and should use the playhouse lot across the street subject to availability. On busy days the lot fills quickly.
 

Additional Parking Options

  • There is a Hikers' Parking Lot located 1/2 mile down Little River Rd from the Visitor Parking Lot for visitors who are just coming to enjoy a hike in the park.
  • Visitors may park behind the Flat Rock Village Offices located at 110 Village Center Drive, Flat Rock, NC. It is a short walk to the park from this lot.
  • Visitors may use the Flat Rock Playhouse lot directly across the street in the morning until noon and in the afternoon when there are no performances. There will be signs posted at the playhouse to restrict parking for performances. Please be a courteous neighbor and pay attention to their signs.
* If you park at Flat Rock Playhouse, remember to move your car before noon or risk being blocked in for several hours on matinee days (Wednesday through Sunday).

Accessibility:
There are 2 accessible parking spaces in the main visitor lot. The walk from the visitor parking lot to the home is 1/3 mile and gains 100 feet in elevation. This can be challenging for many visitors. If you feel this climb may be a challenge for you, please call a park ranger from your cell phone using the phone number posted at the accessible parking spaces. The ranger will either be able to provide a shuttle or will make other accommodations.

properties.name: Margaret's Bedroom
properties.notes:
Margaret's Bedroom
https://www.nps.gov/places/margaret-s-bedroom.htm

Sandburg's oldest daughter Margaret used this room when the family first moved to Connemara.  Later she moved downstairs and the room was used as a guest bedroom. Granddaughter Paula remembers staying here on her visits, and there was a television in the room that Janet watched occasionally.

properties.name: Margaret's Garden and Gazebo
properties.notes:
Margaret's Garden and Gazebo
https://www.nps.gov/places/margaret-s-garden-and-gazebo.htm

The Sandburg's oldest daughter Margaret cared for this "wild, overgrown, and beautiful" fenced garden of roses, peonies and perennials.  She used the gazebo to store her garden tools.

properties.name: McCook, Nebraska
properties.notes:
McCook, Nebraska https://www.nps.gov/places/mccook-nebraska.htm

Carl Sandburg spent very little time in McCook, but the trip there was interesting. Along the way, police officers were checking boxcars for vagrants so Sandburg decided to hide on top of the car. Hanging on for dear life, he traveled from Denver to McCook. Upon arriving, Sandburg dismounted and was immediately told to leave the city.

I climbed down and started to walk out of the yards. A one-eyed man in plain clothes with a club and a star stood in my way. "Where did you come from?" His tone was horstyle. "I just got off that train," I said. He gave me my orders in a more horstyle tone: "We don't want the likes of you in this town. You get back on that train."

And with that, Sandburg climbed back onto the roof of the boxcar and headed out of McCook.

properties.name: Milkhouse
properties.notes:
Milkhouse https://www.nps.gov/places/milkhouse.htm

The Sandburg's built the milk house in 1948 to process and bottle milk for sale on the farm.  Pipes run from the milking parlor inside the barn into the milk house to be strained and separated before bottling.  Quart-size cardboard bottles were affixed with "Connemara Farms" caps and sold to local dairies and individuals.  

After mandatory pasteurization laws were passed in the early 1950's, Mrs. Sandburg no longer sold milk directly, but collected the milk in large containers to be sold to larger dairies for pasteurization and distribution.

properties.name: Mrs. Sandburg's Bedroom
properties.notes:
Mrs. Sandburg's Bedroom https://www.nps.gov/places/mrs-sandburg-s-bedroom.htm

Lilian Steichen Sandburg was married to Carl Sandburg for 59 years.  Carl called her Paula throughout their marriage.  While living at Connemara Sandburg would now and then go to the bay window in her room and lie on the day couch to listen to a record or take a short nap in the afternoon.  Then he and Paula would often go for a walk on the trails behind the house.  

He fell in love with her from the moment they met, and wrote a poem to her called Paula, a portion of which reads: 

When I saw you, I knew you as you knew me.
We knew we had known far back in the eons
When hills were dust and the sea a mist.

properties.name: Nebraska City, Nebraska
properties.notes:
Nebraska City, Nebraska https://www.nps.gov/places/nebraska-city-nebraska.htm

In Nebraska City, Sandburg spent his time picking apples and chopping wood in exchange for two sitdowns (meals at the kitchen table). He also met a lawyer who hired him on to chop wood.

About the lawyer, he wrote:

Seeing my suit of clothes somewhat ragged, [he] asked me if I would like an old suit of his. He brought it out, an iron-gray all-wool suit, better than any I had had in my life.

properties.name: Omaha, Nebraska
properties.notes:
Omaha, Nebraska https://www.nps.gov/places/omaha-nebraska.htm

Omaha was the last city on Sandburg's Hobo Journey.

For work in Omaha, he was a dishwasher at the Hotel Mercer for a dollar and fifty cents a week. Unfortunately, for the second time on his journey, Sandburg worked a job without pay.

He writes:

It was a little queer how standard was the wage rate for a dishwasher. It never went as low as a dollar and twenty-five cents a week nor a high as a dollar and seventy-five cents a week... The hotel was leased and run by a fancily dressed tall man who slid and slunk rather than walked around the place. He was known as Wink Taylor... At the end of the first week I didn't get my standard pay of a dollar and fifty cents nor likewise at the end of the second week. Then came the word that the Hotel Mercer was closed, gone, up the spout, foreclosed, and Wink Taylor vanished.

In his writings about Omaha, Carl Sandburg reflected that during his travels he had considered joining the Army multiple times. He remembered walking past the recruiting offices in Kansas City, Denver, and Omaha, but each time he neglected to go inside. Sandburg would eventually go on to join and serve during the Spanish-American War.

properties.name: Park Store and Information
properties.notes:
Park Store and Information https://www.nps.gov/places/carl-park-store.htm The Visitor Center/Park Store is open Wednesday to Sunday (5 days per week) from 10am to 4pm, inside the Sandburg Home. The online park store is open everyday!

The Park Store and visitor information area is a great place to start your visit! You can find information to plan your visit, get a passport stamp, participate in the Jr Ranger or BARK Ranger programs, and get a schedule of upcoming events. 

The park store is operated by America's National Parks, an official non-profit partner of the National Park Service dedicated to supporting the educational mission of Carl Sandburg Home NHS. The park store has a wide range of books, media, educational games, and other items available for retail sale. These products complement the interpretive themes you experience when visiting the park. The park store is located in the Sandburg Home or you can visit the online park store.

properties.name: Pump House
properties.notes:
Pump House
https://www.nps.gov/places/pump-house.htm

From the 1830s until the 1980's this building provided water for the early residents and even park visitors to Connemara.  A reservoir located near the top of Glassy Mountain provided the water supply.  A pump in this building then sent water to the house, the pond in front of the house and down to the barn.

properties.name: Salida, Colorado
properties.notes:
Salida, Colorado https://www.nps.gov/places/salida-colorado.htm

After Lakin, Sandburg left Kansas. He slept in a boxcar as the train headed towards Colorado. When he awoke the next morning he looked up and found himself in the Rocky Mountains.

My eyes caught high rises of tumbling land I had never met before. "Jesus," I said, "those are the Rocky Mountains." I hadn't planned it but there they were, rolling formations of rock and pine lifted away high. "There's the Hand of God." I said.

Sandburg spent two days in Salida where he picked pears and earned a few half-dollars.

properties.name: Sandburg Home
properties.notes:
Sandburg Home https://www.nps.gov/places/sandburg-home-tour.htm

Access to the Sandburg Home is currently closed due to Covid-19. 

Sandburg stood on the porch of his new home in Flat Rock, NC, and declared, "We didn’t just buy two-hundred and forty-five acres when we bought Connemara, we bought a million acres of sky!  They also found at Connemara a writer’s sanctuary and the perfect farm for dairy goats.

As you tour the house you will note that the Sandburg family lived casually.  Simplicity was the rule as indicated by the functional furnishings.

Sandburg followed this philosophy throughout his life, having written to his soon-to-be wife Lilian in 1908, “All the big people are simple, as simple as the unexplored wilderness. They love the universal things that are free to everybody. Light and air and food and love and some work are enough. In the varying phases of these cheap and common things, the great lives have found their joy.”

Connemara provided them all these things; mountain air, gardens and orchards full of vegetables and fruit, plenty of work, and the love of a family.

Tours of the home are offered daily from 9:30 am to 4:30 pm.  Step inside the ground floor of the house to learn more and visit the bookstore.

properties.name: Sandburg Home - Janet Sandburg's Bedroom
properties.notes:
Sandburg Home - Janet Sandburg's Bedroom
https://www.nps.gov/places/tour-janet.htm

Sandburg's middle daughter Janet helped out with the farm work, getting up every morning at 5:30 am to feed the baby goats.  Later in the day she helped with the housework.  In her room, she read, drew, wrote letters, and compiled scrapbooks.

properties.name: Sandburg Home Carl Sandburg's Bedroom
properties.notes:
Sandburg Home Carl Sandburg's Bedroom https://www.nps.gov/places/tour-sandburg-bedroom.htm

Carl wanted his study and bedroom located on the west side of the house because he knew that he would be working throughout the night and sleeping late in the morning and he did not want the rising sun to disturb this routine.

After waking in mid-morning, he exercised, doing calisthenics using Indian clubs seen resting against the chair, listening to classical or folk music on his phonograph player, and reading a little before coming downstairs for the day. Clippings of interesting articles and images from magazines hang pinned to the wall.

properties.name: Sandburg Home Carl Sandburg's Study
properties.notes:
Sandburg Home Carl Sandburg's Study https://www.nps.gov/places/tour-study.htm

Carl Sandburg did most of his writing in his upstairs workroom, amid a clutter of papers, books, filing crates, and boxes. He pinned notes and newspaper clippings to the walls and shelves. He’d peck away with two fingers at his typewriter, which often was perched on an orange crate.

Sandburg completed several books while at Connemara; his novel Remembrance Rock, a one volume edition of the six-volume Abraham Lincoln Biography, his own autobiography titled Always the Young Strangers, and compiled his Pulitzer Prize-winning Complete Poems.

properties.name: Sandburg Home Correspondence Room
properties.notes:
Sandburg Home Correspondence Room https://www.nps.gov/places/tour-sandburg-office.htm

This study served as an office where Sandburg worked on correspondence and manuscripts, either with the assistance of a secretary or his daughters Margaret and Helga.  The room was usually piled high with filing boxes and books.  The books lining the shelves were loosely organized according to subjects and projects. 

Sandburg read the many letters sent to him daily; mail from his publisher, fellow poets, school children reading and studying his poetry, U.S. Senators, Supreme Court Justices, and even mail from various Presidents of the United States that he had befriended over the years.

A prominent feature of this room is the table constructed from timbers that supported the roof of the White House during Lincoln’s presidency.  The lumber was salvaged from a renovation project at the White House by carpenter George Severin, He used the wood to construct the table as a gift for Carl Sandburg in honor of his Pulitzer prize-winning biography of Abraham Lincoln.

Click below for an audio clip from Sandburg's address to Congress on the occasion of Abraham Lincoln's 150th birthday in 1959.

properties.name: Sandburg Home Dining Room
properties.notes:
Sandburg Home Dining Room https://www.nps.gov/places/tour-dining-room.htm

The aromas of freshly baked breads, hearty soups or homemade pies filled the Sandburg dining room. Most meals included fresh garden salads, yogurt, goat's milk, and Mrs. Sandburg's special cheeses. Carl Sandburg's red thermos contained fresh brewed coffee with goat's milk and a spoonful of honey.  

While they were a very busy and independent family with a host of varied interests, they came together whenever possible for lunch and dinner. After dinner, Sandburg would often play his guitar for a family sing-a-long, or read from his current work.  Or they might turn on the radio to hear Jack Benny, Fibber McGee and Molly or the evening news. Birds entertained outside while they sat around the table.

properties.name: Sandburg Home Farm Office
properties.notes:
Sandburg Home Farm Office https://www.nps.gov/places/tour-farm-office.htm

From her office in the middle of the house, Mrs. Sandburg paid the bills, answered correspondence and kept both the house and farm running smoothly.  She took care of the day to day business so that her husband could focus on his writing.

In order to manage the large goat herd, Mrs. Sandburg was often in her office studying goat lineages, calculating bloodlines and making breeding decisions based on science. She was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate from the University of Chicago, and had a keen interest in genetics. She sold milk to local dairies, sold goats to North and South America, and kept an active schedule of showing goats at regional contests.

Click the audio below to learn how Mrs. Sandburg and her daughter Helga first started raising dairy goats.

properties.name: Sandburg Home Kitchen
properties.notes:
Sandburg Home Kitchen https://www.nps.gov/places/tour-kitchen.htm

Using fresh vegetables from the garden and meat from the farm or market, all meals were prepared in this kitchen, with the family rarely having a meal out. 

This room only contained a sink and small counter when the Sandburg's moved in since the original kitchen to the home was in an adjacent building. Mrs. Sandburg had new metal cabinets, a refrigerator and even a dishwasher installed here. The oven came from their home in Michigan.

properties.name: Sandburg Home Living Room
properties.notes:
Sandburg Home Living Room https://www.nps.gov/places/tour-living-room.htm

Friends and family were entertained in this room, with Carl playing folk music on his guitar and singing, or sharing stories. His daughter Margaret often joined in on the piano. The walls are adorned with photographs by Edward Steichen, Mrs. Sandburg’s brother, and of course Sandburg’s books. An entire boxcare was filled with the 14,000 books Sandburg brought with him from Michigan.  

Not one to point out his own accomplishments,he stored his Presidential Medal of Freedem, his medal from the King of Sweden and his honorary doctorate degrees in a glass cabinet in the corner.

properties.name: Sandburg Home Mrs. Sandburg's Bedroom
properties.notes:
Sandburg Home Mrs. Sandburg's Bedroom https://www.nps.gov/places/tour-mrs-bedroom.htm

Lilian Steichen Sandburg was married to Carl Sandburg for 59 years.  Carl called her Paula throughout their marriage.  While living at Connemara Sandburg would now and then go to the bay window in her room and lie on the day couch to listen to a record or take a short nap in the afternoon.  Then he and Paula would often go for a walk on the trails behind the house.  

He fell in love with her from the moment they met, and wrote a poem to her called Paula, a portion of which reads: 

When I saw you, I knew you as you knew me.
We knew we had known far back in the eons
When hills were dust and the sea a mist.

Listen to Carl Sandburg read an excerpt from another love poem below.

properties.name: Sandburg's Hobo Homecoming
properties.notes:
Sandburg's Hobo Homecoming
https://www.nps.gov/places/sandburg-s-hobo-homecoming.htm

Sandburg arrived in Galesburg on October 15, I caught one freight train after another till I came in sight of Galesburg the afternoon of October fifteenth. I walked along Berrien Street till I came to the only house in the United States where I could open a door without knocking and walk in for a kiss from the woman of the house. They gave me a sitdown and as they had had only two or three letters from me, they asked me where I had been and I told them the half of it. When I showed my father fifteen dollars and a few nickels, he said the money would come in handy and I should watch it. What had the trip done to me? I couldn’t say. It had changed me. I was easier about looking people in the eye. When questions came I was quicker at answering them or turning them off. I had been a young stranger meeting many odd strangers and I had practiced at having answers... Away deep in my heart now I had hope as never before. Struggles lay ahead, I was sure, but whatever they were I would not be afraid of them.

properties.name: Sandburg's Hobo Journey
properties.notes: Sandburg's Hobo Journey https://www.nps.gov/places/sandburg-s-hobo-journey.htm Follow Carl Sandburg's hobo journey, beginning in his hometown of Galesburg, Illinois and ending in Omaha, Nebraska. Visit the cities below to learn about Sandburg's time riding the rails. LIbrary of Congress images used below are for historical context only and do not depict Carl Sandburg or people he knew.

properties.name: Sandburg's Upstairs Study
properties.notes:
Sandburg's Upstairs Study https://www.nps.gov/places/sandburg-s-upstairs-study.htm

Carl Sandburg did most of his writing in his upstairs workroom, amid a clutter of papers, books, filing crates, and boxes. He pinned notes and newspaper clippings to the walls and shelves. He’d peck away with two fingers at his typewriter, which often was perched on an orange crate.

properties.name: Spring House
properties.notes:
Spring House https://www.nps.gov/places/spring-house.htm

Cool water from a mountain reservoir flowed through the spring house providing a perfect place for Mrs. Sandburg and her daughter Helga to store and cure cheeses made from goat's milk.

Listen to the audio for a description of the cheeses cured here from Mrs. Sandburg's granddaughter Paula Steichen.

"Then we had a little cheese house on the…if you continue on the Memminger path, where my grandmother and mother did make the most wonderful cheeses of all different sorts and flavored them with anise seeds and with all number of herbs. My mother actually wrote an article called “Making Goat Cheese” for the dairy goat journal I believe it was."

properties.name: Swedish House
properties.notes:
Swedish House
https://www.nps.gov/places/swedish-house.htm

This building housed the servants of the first two owners.  Carl Sandburg later named it the "Swedish House" because of the scalloped fascia and used it as an overflow library for magazines and books.

properties.name: TRACK Trail
properties.notes:
TRACK Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/track-trail.htm

Enjoy the peaceful setting while discovering what makes the farm, fields and forests so unique at Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site. Pick up a TRACK Trail brochure as you enter the park from the main visitor parking lot. 

The brochures help young visitors discover different aspects of the park as they visit the Sandburg residence, the goat farm, rolling pastures, mountainside woods, miles of hiking trails, two lakes, flower and vegetable gardens, and an apple orchard.

To download and print a brochure before you come or to find more TRACK trails in the area, visit kidsinparks.com.

properties.name: Tenant House
properties.notes:
Tenant House
https://www.nps.gov/places/tenant-house.htm

Built around 1910, this "little white house" was a residence for farm assisstants, chauffers and family guests of the Smyth family.  During Sandburg's time it was occasionally used as a residence for farm employees or as a studio for Helga Sandburg's painting.

properties.name: The Farm Manager's House
properties.notes:
The Farm Manager's House https://www.nps.gov/places/the-farm-manager-s-house.htm

This residence was constructed around 1915 to serve as the home for Smyth's farm caretaker and his family.  The Sandburg's continued this use when they hired Frank Mintz in 1946 to tend Connemara Farms.  He helped by feeding, milking and breeding the goats, plowing the fields and making repairs to buildings.

In the 1960's Leroy Levi moved in with his family to serve as farm manager.  Today the house is used as a residence for temporaray employees and in the spring for the Carl Sandburg Writer-in-Residence.

properties.name: The Horse Barn
properties.notes:
The Horse Barn https://www.nps.gov/places/the-horse-barn.htm Access to see this building is limited due to Covid-19

The grandchildren, Paula and John Carl each had a horse to ride through the pastures and along the many trails throughout the property. This building housed their horses, saddles and tack.  Work horses for plowing were also kept here.

properties.name: The Journey Begins: A Hobo Tour Intro
properties.notes: The Journey Begins: A Hobo Tour Intro https://www.nps.gov/places/the-journey-begins-a-hobo-tour-intro.htm At the age of 19 Carl Sandburg was a restless young man, anxious to find himself and to see the country. Prior to  his Hobo adventure Sandburg had only traveled as far as  Chicago. He was drawn to head west to Kansas, in time for the wheat harvest, where there would surely be work. Along the way, he would stop to find odd jobs to fund his travels and to keep food in his belly. Sandburg left his friends and family in Galesburg Ill on the last week of June in 1897, he returned to his hometown on October 15th of that same year.  In reference to his hobo travels, Sandburg wrote, I was meeting fellow traveler's and fellow Americans and  what they were doing to my heart and mind, my personality; I could not say then nor later and be certain. I was getting a deeper self-respect than I had in Galesburg, so much I knew. I was getting to be a better storyteller! Quotes used in this tour are Sandburg's own from "Always the Young Stranger". Maps are provided by Library of Congress.

properties.name: Visit Connemara Farms
properties.notes:
Visit Connemara Farms https://www.nps.gov/places/connemara-farms.htm

Outdoor access to the goats (in the barnyard and pasture) is available from 10am to 4pm daily. 

Visitors to Connemara Farms can see dairy goats that are descended from Mrs. Sandburg's famous herd. She raised three breeds of dairy goats; Saanen, Toggenburg, and Nubian. Each breed can be seen in the herd today.

Mrs. Sandburg owned and operated a goat dairy from 1935 to 1965. Here at Connemara, Mrs. Sandburg's goat breeding program produced champion goats and led to the improvement of goats as milk producing animals.

Rangers and volunteers are on hand to share this fascinating story about goats and Mrs. Sandburg's dairy goat operation. Learn more here.

properties.name: Woodshed
properties.notes:
Woodshed
https://www.nps.gov/places/woodshed.htm

In addition to storing wood for the fireplaces, the Sandburg's stored older farm equipment here including a poultry feeder, a baby chick house, cream seperator, plows, mowers and unused building materials.
